description: Master the core philosophy and lifecycle of Test-Driven Development to write cleaner, safer code

slides.title: What is TDD?
slides.content:
# Test-Driven Development (TDD) ðŸ§ª

A software development process where you write tests **before** you write the actual code.

- **Philosophy**: Tests shouldn't just verify code; they should **drive** the design of the code.
- **Mantra**: "Never write a single line of code without a failing test first."

slides.title: The TDD Lifecycle
slides.content:
# Red-Green-Refactor ðŸ”„

1. ðŸ”´ **Red**: Write a test that fails (since the feature doesn't exist yet).
2. ðŸŸ¢ **Green**: Write the **minimum** amount of code to make the test pass.
3. ðŸ”µ **Refactor**: Improve the code structure while keeping the test passing.

slides.title: Why TDD?
slides.content:
# Benefits ðŸŒŸ

- **Confidence**: You know your code works because you have proof.
- **Design**: Leads to modular, decoupled code (otherwise it's hard to test!).
- **Documentation**: Tests serve as clear examples of how to use your code.
- **Bug Reduction**: Catches errors at the moment of creation.

slides.title: TDD vs Traditional Testing
slides.content:
# The Paradigm Shift ðŸ§ 

| Traditional | TDD |
|-------------|-----|
| Write Code âž¡ï¸ Write Tests | Write Tests âž¡ï¸ Write Code |
| Testing is a separate phase | Testing is the development process |
| Often results in high coupling | Promotes loose coupling |

slides.content: Mastering the cycle.

slides.title: Small Steps
slides.content:
# Baby Steps ðŸ‘£

TDD is about incremental progress. Don't try to build the whole feature at once.

1. Use a test to define a tiny requirement.
2. Implement just enough to satisfy it.
3. Repeat.

slides.title: Uncle Bob's Laws
slides.content:
# The Three Laws of TDD ðŸ“œ

1. You are not allowed to write any production code unless it is to make a failing unit test pass.
2. You are not allowed to write any more of a unit test than is sufficient to fail.
3. You are not allowed to write any more production code than is sufficient to pass the one failing unit test.

slides.title: Minimal Implementation
slides.content:
# Faking it to Green ðŸŸ¢

It is okay to hardcode a return value just to make the test green, then write another test that forces you to implement real logic!

```javascript
// Test: adds(1,1) expecting 2
const add = (a, b) => 2; // Green! Now write 2+2=4 to force a+b.
```

slides.title: Test Quality
slides.content:
# Fast and Focused âš¡

TDD tests should be **fast**. If your tests take minutes to run, you will stop doing TDD. Keep them isolated and use mocks for heavy dependencies.

slides.title: Laws Quiz
slides.content: Strict rules.

slides.title: Refactoring in TDD
slides.content:
# The 'Third' Step ðŸ”µ

Refactoring is **not** optional. Once the test is green, look for:
- Duplication.
- Poor naming.
- Large methods.
- Unclear logic.

> ðŸ’¡ You can refactor safely because your tests will tell you if you broke something!

slides.title: Emotional TDD
slides.content:
# Focus ðŸ§˜

TDD reduces anxiety. Instead of worrying about 10 requirements, you only worry about the **one** failing test in front of you.

slides.title: Unit vs Functional TDD
slides.content:
# Two Levels â¬†ï¸

- **Double Loop TDD**: Write a failing functional (E2E/Integ) test, then write multiple failing unit tests to build the components needed to pass that functional test.

slides.title: When TDD is hard
slides.content:
# Challenges ðŸ§—

- **Legacy Code**: Hard to test if not built with TDD.
- **UI/Visuals**: Logic is easy, layout is harder.
- **Heavy Dependencies**: Requires skillful mocking.

slides.content: Expanding the scope.

slides.title: Code Coverage in TDD
slides.content:
# High Coverage ðŸ“ˆ

One side effect of TDD is very high code coverage (90%+), since you literally don't write code that isn't asked for by a test.

slides.title: Test as Documentation
slides.content:
# Executable Specs ðŸ“š

New developers can read your tests to see exactly how the system is expected to behave. It never gets out of date!

slides.title: The Cost of TDD
slides.content:
# Time Investment â±ï¸

TDD might feel slower at first (writing 2x the code), but it saves massive amounts of time during maintenance and bug fixing later.

slides.title: Tooling
slides.content:
# Ecosystem ðŸ› ï¸

TDD works with any testing tool (Jest, JUnit, RSpec), but it works best with those that have **Watch Mode** (auto-running tests on save).
